abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Minas Gerais Development
            Partnership Project received a satisfactory development
            outcome with moderate risk to development outcome. The Bank
            received a satisfactory rating for their performance while
            the Borrower received a highly satisfactory performance
            rating. There were several restructuring this project went
            through, five in total. The result of each restructuring was
            an extension of the closing date. The first restructuring
            was to address a financing gap arising from unanticipated
            circumstances, and to scale up project activities. The
            second procurement was due to delays in procurement
            processes required an extension of the closing date to allow
            for the full disbursement of the technical assistance
            component. The third restructuring provided an extension to
            allow for the implementation of two consultancies (a
            feasibility study on a train network and an Economic Master
            Plan for the Belo Horizonte metropolitan area) in the
            technical assistance component. The fourth restructuring
            extended to closing date to be able to use remaining funds
            under the TA component to extend the scope of the Economic
            Master Plan consultancy by including 14 additional
            municipalities in the study. The final restructuring
            extended to closing date due to delays in approving the
            procurement of the last contract (Economic Master Plan
            consultancy). Several lessons were taken from this project
            including the following: (1) the importance of a technical
            assistance component to foster innovation, (2) the
            value-added through technical assistance provided by the
            Bank, (3) the importance of technical assistance as a
            vehicle for continued dialogue, (4) disbursement-linked
            indicators as a performance push, (5) attention needs to be
            given to the design of the DLIs, and (6) the financing of
            eligible expenditure programs (EEPs) can serve to protect
            certain categories of spending in certain sectors.
